text: Nice one. I like the idea of the creature and the image. While you re building a folio, don’t worry about timing, try to just do the best job you can as that is what you are going to be judged on.
Here are some thoughts to think about it you want to add more polish:

Around the mouth and teeth area, they feel very thin. Try adding more thickness as it will seem more realistic. I used to have this problem when modeling eyelids - you will see that they are actually fleshy and thick.

Consider the type of material the teeth and everything else is made from. This is not just the texture, but the level of translucency and shininess. At this depth, a lot of creatures are transparent in some way

On the creature’s skin, it is very much one color. Look at some creatures to see how the color variation changes across their bodies. Often they will have one color on their bellies, a color change, then a focused area of detail
On the model, be careful about volume loss in the shoulder area and the mesh collision on the right hand
Other than that, it’s looking really nice. Keep plugging away :)

Consider your throat area which there is not more detail. The way you have framed and lit this image has made the mouth and the throat the focal point of the shot. With little detail it feels a bit empty. You should think about this area and actually model a proper throat area. If it felt fleshy and organic, it would be a great feature

The light is a little distracting because you start to question what it is. I know at this sea depth it is quite dark, but you have a light source almost under lighting this creature which is not really possible. If these lights were from a sub (camera pov), then you may need to be a bit higher to feel realistic as it wouldn’t get that low. You could also add some bounce light from this light too which would add more form.

Even though the light source from a sub would be a hard source, the light underwater would scatter and wrap around your creature. If you are not rendering in Global illumination, which I think you should do for stills, you need to fake this with multiple lights with tiny amounts

Also, just for an experiment, take your image into photoshop, duplicate your image, blur the duplicate, then use a “screen” blending mode to apply it down to the previous image. Make the transparency of this layer about 30%
This is a way of creating a fake bloom - scattering of light that is useful when dealing with underwater or fog.
You want your image to be single source lit, but the shadows and light to feel like it wraps around your model

Also, consider focus. Underwater there is little light and so the camera aperture needs to be wide open and there will be shallow depth of field. The background and edges of frame should fall out of focus somewhat.
Anyhow, that’s all. Apologies for the chunk of information, but I hope it’s helpful to you :)

Thank you for the feedback yes I agree that the creature is a bit under lit I did look at references of deep sea photography they do usually have one light source, either from the camera itself or the submarine. As for the textures I was going for the shark colours they are usually two toned but if the colour scheme is not working then its not working. I will do what you have suggested and add bloom and more atmospherics.
